text:
Centre Street, west side, from Leonard to Franklin Street, showing the Tombs (built in 1840) under demolition. In the foreground appears a horse drawn street car of the Fourth and Madison Ave. lines which operated between the Post Office and Mott Haven in Harlem.

1897.

Ewing Galloway.

original_title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Between Franklin and White Streets.
text:
New York Criminal Courts Building, (Center of prosecuting activities)
Apr. 30, 1914
American Press Assn.

Centre Street, west side, north from and including Franklin Street. This view shows the Criminal Courts Building, followed by the Department of Health Building.

May 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Nos. 112 to 130 Centre Street, east side, north from Franklin to White (left) Streets, showing the westerly side of the northern half of this new Criminal Courts Building site, prior to clearance. No. 2 is the same location, viewed northerly and showing a more view; while No. 3, the 7-story loft structure (No. 127-130 Centre Also No. 121 White Street) at the S.E. corner of these two streets.

November 2, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Building on N.E. Corner was Thomas J. Foley saloon and Office. No 112 Centre St.

Nos. 112 to 130 Centre Street, east side, north from Franklin to White (left) Streets, showing the westerly side of the northern half of this new Criminal Courts Building site, prior to clearance. No. 2 is the same location, viewed northerly and showing a more view; while No. 3, the 7-story loft structure (No. 127-130 Centre Also No. 121 White Street) at the S.E. corner of these two streets.

November 2, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Building on N.E. Corner was Thomas J. Foley saloon and Office. No 112 Centre St.

Nos. 112 to 130 Centre Street, east side, north from Franklin to White (left) Streets, showing the westerly side of the northern half of this new Criminal Courts Building site, prior to clearance. No. 2 is the same location, viewed northerly and showing a more view; while No. 3, the 7-story loft structure (No. 127-130 Centre Also No. 121 White Street) at the S.E. corner of these two streets.

November 2, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Building on N.E. Corner was Thomas J. Foley saloon and Office. No 112 Centre St.

(1)
Franklin Street, east from Centre to Baxter Streets, showing on both sides, clearances upon which will rise the new Criminal Courts Bldg. and prison. These will replace the old Court Bldg. and the Tombs on the opposite side of Centre Street. For an account of same, see the New York Times of Aug. 1, 1938, page 21.

P. L. Sperr

(2)
A northeastward view across the northly unit, to show buildings at the N.E. corner of Baxter (left) and Bayard (right) Streets. To the right of same appears P.S. No. 23 at the N.E. corner of Bayard and Mulberry Street and a portion of Columbus Park.

June 18, 1938.

P. L. Sperr

(1)
Franklin Street, east from Centre to Baxter Streets, showing on both sides, clearances upon which will rise the new Criminal Courts Bldg. and prison. These will replace the old Court Bldg. and the Tombs on the opposite side of Centre Street. For an account of same, see the New York Times of Aug. 1, 1938, page 21.

P. L. Sperr

(2)
A northeastward view across the northly unit, to show buildings at the N.E. corner of Baxter (left) and Bayard (right) Streets. To the right of same appears P.S. No. 23 at the N.E. corner of Bayard and Mulberry Street and a portion of Columbus Park.

June 18, 1938.

P. L. Sperr

Franklin Street, west from Centre to Lafayette Streets, showing a portion of the Tombs and its "Bridge of Sighs" leading from the Criminal Courts Building.

1939

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
